* adding ROS API to probe for wind speed

content.raw:
We should probably update the wiki [#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/ChangingPluginParameters](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/ChangingPluginParameters)

And add some notes about the new functionality.
content.html:

content.raw: I believe all the comments have been addressed. Could you add a new entry to the `Changelog.md` file? We are ready to approve and merge.
content.html: I believe all the comments have been addressed. Could you add a new entry to the Changelog.md file? We are ready to approve and merge.

content.raw: We don't really have a rule for spacing, use your best judging. In terms of ordering, typically `.h` headers first, then, standard c\+\+ headers, then, other C\+\+ headers, and then, your own `.hh` headers.
content.html: We don't really have a rule for spacing, use your best judging. In terms of ordering, typically .h headers first, then, standard c++ headers, then, other C++ headers, and then, your own .hh headers.

update.description:
* enabling the user to input only the angle for wind direction
* adding ROS API to probe for wind speed
update.title: Issue#91 wind plugin ROS interface

content.raw: So the way I am doing it right now is the exact opposite? I am setting the \+ve direction and traditionally people state where originates from \(i.e the negative direction?\)
content.html: So the way I am doing it right now is the exact opposite? I am setting the +ve direction and traditionally people state where originates from (i.e the negative direction?)

content.raw:
I was thinking that too but I reconsidered when I examined all the places `this->windDirection` is being used. 

For example `windDirection` needs to be a `ignition::math::Vector3d` for this calculation.

```c++
   ignition::math::Vector3d relativeWind =
     this->link->WorldPose().Rot().Inverse().RotateVector(
       this->windDirection*velocity);
```
content.html:
I was thinking that too but I reconsidered when I examined all the places this->windDirection is being used.

For example windDirection needs to be a ignition::math::Vector3d for this calculation.

   ignition::math::Vector3d relativeWind =
     this->link->WorldPose().Rot().Inverse().RotateVector(
       this->windDirection*velocity);

content.raw: Could you document this parameter in the header file too? Including the behavior if the value is `-1` or `0`.
content.html: Could you document this parameter in the header file too? Including the behavior if the value is -1 or 0.

content.raw: Agree on this comment. This will be relevant when running the competition where we’ll want to disable this feature.
content.html: Agree on this comment. This will be relevant when running the competition where we’ll want to disable this feature.

content.raw: Could you add this new feature to the `Changelog.md` please?
content.html: Could you add this new feature to the Changelog.md please?

content.raw: Given that we're moving to a 2D angle, does it make sense to convert `this->windDirection` to an `ignition::math::Angle`?
content.html: Given that we're moving to a 2D angle, does it make sense to convert this->windDirection to an ignition::math::Angle?

content.raw: Nitpick: Could you move it before line `27`. Typically, `.h` should be declared before the `.hh` headers.
content.html: Nitpick: Could you move it before line 27. Typically, .h should be declared before the .hh headers.

content.raw: I believe this method of setting the windDirection means that the user is specifying the positive direction of the wind vector.   Traditionally wind direction is specified as the direction from which the wind is coming from, e.g., an “easterly” wind results in a wind vector pointing to the west.   We can use either convention for the “wind\_direction” parameter, just need to document it clearly in the header file comments.  For the current implementation may say something like “Wind direction is specified as the positive direction of the wind velocity vector in the horizontal plane in degrees using the ENU coordinate convention.”
content.html: I believe this method of setting the windDirection means that the user is specifying the positive direction of the wind vector. Traditionally wind direction is specified as the direction from which the wind is coming from, e.g., an “easterly” wind results in a wind vector pointing to the west. We can use either convention for the “wind_direction” parameter, just need to document it clearly in the header file comments. For the current implementation may say something like “Wind direction is specified as the positive direction of the wind velocity vector in the horizontal plane in degrees using the ENU coordinate convention.”

content.raw:
Would it be more intuitive to have the user supply an “update\_rate” in Hz to specify the publication frequency?  That seems to be a more common interface for sensor-type plugins.  Perhaps: 

* Setting update rate to -1 \(or any negative value\) would have the publications happen each update cycle
* Setting the update rate to 0 would mean the plugin never publishes velocity and direction.
content.html:
Would it be more intuitive to have the user supply an “update_rate” in Hz to specify the publication frequency? That seems to be a more common interface for sensor-type plugins. Perhaps:

  • Setting update rate to -1 (or any negative value) would have the publications happen each update cycle
  • Setting the update rate to 0 would mean the plugin never publishes velocity and direction.

content.raw:
This looks really great - thank you. 

One requested addition. As you mentioned, for the purposes of the competition we’d want to turn off the ROS publications - otherwise the teams would have access to a perfect wind sensor. Could you add a plugin parameter to allow the user to turn on/off the ROS publications?
content.html:
This looks really great - thank you.

One requested addition. As you mentioned, for the purposes of the competition we’d want to turn off the ROS publications - otherwise the teams would have access to a perfect wind sensor. Could you add a plugin parameter to allow the user to turn on/off the ROS publications?

content.raw: I just saw how it was done from “stationkeeping\_scoring\_plugin.cc”
content.html: I just saw how it was done from “stationkeeping_scoring_plugin.cc”
